security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown text. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, no environment variable access. This skill provides guidance on configuring Claude Code hookify rules and presents no security risk.

content.user_title: Create Hookify Rules for Claude Code
content.value_statement: Claude Code users often create dangerous commands or forget safety checks without realizing it. This skill provides comprehensive guidance on creating hookify rules that automatically warn or block problematic patterns before they cause harm.
actual_capabilities: Create hookify rule files with YAML frontmatter in .claude directory
Define regex patterns to match bash commands, file edits, or prompts
Configure rule actions: warn (show message) or block (prevent operation)
Build multi-condition rules using fields like file_path, new_text, command
Use operators: regex_match, contains, equals, not_contains, starts_with, ends_with
Trigger rules on events: bash, file, stop, prompt, or all events
limitations: Only provides guidance documentation - does not create or modify files directly
Rules apply only within Claude Code sessions using hookify feature
Pattern matching is limited to regex and simple string operations
Does not execute code or access external APIs

best_practices: Use specific regex patterns rather than broad matches to avoid false positives
Test patterns with Python regex or regex101.com before deploying rules
Add rules to .gitignore to prevent committing local project-specific rules
anti_patterns: Using overly broad patterns like 'log' which matches login, dialog, catalog
Creating rules without messages explaining why the pattern was detected
Using too many conditions that make rules hard to maintain and debug

faq.question: What event types can hookify rules trigger on?
faq.answer: Five event types: bash (shell commands), file (edit/write operations), stop (agent completion), prompt (user input), and all (any event).

faq.question: What is the difference between warn and block actions?
faq.answer: Warn shows a message but allows the operation to continue. Block prevents the operation entirely or stops the session depending on event type.

faq.question: Can hookify rules access my files or environment variables?
faq.answer: No. Hookify rules are pattern matching definitions that only read tool inputs like command text or file content being edited.

faq.question: How do I test if my regex pattern works correctly?
faq.answer: Use Python: python3 -c "import re; print(re.search(r'pattern', 'test string'))" or use regex101.com with Python flavor.

faq.question: How do hookify rules compare to .claude/rules.md?
faq.answer: Hookify rules are reactive patterns that trigger during tool use with warnings or blocks. Rules.md provides proactive instructions that run on every turn.

faq.question: What naming convention should I use for hookify rule files?
faq.answer: Use format: .claude/hookify.{descriptive-name}.local.md with kebab-case names like hookify.dangerous-rm.local.md
